pullRequest.body:
Shows one of the key technical lemmas about Galois categories, namely that evaluation on a point of the fibre of morphisms out of a connected object is injective.

Also adds some more basic properties on when objects are initial and preservation and reflection of monomorphisms.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: Thank's for the detailed feedback @kbuzzard. I applied your suggestions, I just have one question on one of the remarks above.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7746954131/job/21126344416)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7746954131/job/21126343633)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7746954131/job/21126344175)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Thanks a lot for formalising this interesting material!
Looking good to me. Just one minor comment.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← equalizerComparison_comp_π f g F] ```

I don't think you need this instance. If you `#synth PreservesMonomorphisms F` it works fine without it (and finds the term which you supply). Sometimes people do make instances which can be synthesized already by the system but this is typically to help typeclass inference find shortcuts and speed things up.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
  haveI : IsIso (pullback.fst : pullback (F.map f) (F.map f) ⟶ F.obj X) :=
```
and the same for the `have`s on lines 137 and 140. If you write `instance foo : ReflectsMonomorphisms...` (i.e. give it a name) and then `#print foo` with the three `have`s and then with the three `haveI`s, you see that the term created by the code is much cleaner with the `haveI`s: there are no random `let`s clogging things up. This doesn't matter at all really, because this is a proof so who cares what it looks like, but my instinct with these sorts of arguments in general (adding stuff to the typeclass system to make other arguments work) is to use `haveI` (I for "inline").

```suggestion
  map_injective {X Y} f g h := by
```
(golfy mathlib culture)

```suggestion
    Nonempty (IsInitial X) ↔ Nonempty (IsInitial (G.obj X)) :=
  ⟨fun ⟨h⟩ ↦ ⟨IsInitial.isInitialObj G X h⟩ , fun ⟨h⟩ ↦ ⟨IsInitial.isInitialOfObj G X h⟩⟩
```
You can just write the term.
Why are you making these lemmas private? I could imagine others needing them. Probably they would need to go in other files?

I moved the one for `Type u` in the corresponding file. The one for `FintypeCat` I am not sure about: There is no file `CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.FintypeCat` yet and I think I once asked @joelriou a similar question and they said, they prefer not introducing such a file and instead formulating statements like this for `ConcreteCategory`. In this case I am unsure if this is worth the generality? This holds for full subcategories of `Type u` that have the empty set, so I might as well say it holds for `FintypeCat`.

One could formulate a general statement for concrete categories whose forgetful functor preserves the appropriate kind of colimit. I think such a lemma would be worth having (along with an analogous one for terminal objects.

I have now put some API on initials and terminals in concrete categories. Is this what you head in mind @adamtopaz ? Maybe we can somehow make the `forget FintypeCat` definition reducible, so that it automatically infers the instances from `FintypeCat.incl`? See the additional `haveI`s in the new version.

```suggestion
/- An object is not initial, if its fibre is inhabited. -/
```

```suggestion
/- The fibre of a connected object is nonempty. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The fibre of the equalizer of `f g : X ⟶ Y` is equivalent to the set of agreement of `f` and `g`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The evaluation map is injective for connected objects. -/
```
There is no harm in making these comments into docstrings.

```suggestion
    Function.Injective (fun f : Aut A ↦ F.map (f.hom) a) := by
```
(and twice on the next line): I think that `↦` is the mathlib convention?

```suggestion
  · exact evaluationInjective_of_connected F A A a
  · exact @Aut.ext _ _ A
```

```suggestion
instance : ReflectsMonomorphisms F := ReflectsMonomorphisms.mk <| by
```
You can choose a name if you want.
Good catch, I added this earlier to analyze @kbuzzard s Remark.
Can this go a more basic file? And I think there is no need to have it private.

See the discussion above. Should I just make a new file `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.FintypeCat`? Or do you have a different suggestion? Maybe this can be generalized to concrete categories somehow?

```suggestion
/-- An object whose fibre is inhabited is not initial. -/
lemma not_initial_of_inhabited {X : C} (x : F.obj X) : ¬(IsInitial X) :=
  ((initial_iff_fibre_empty F X).mp ⟨h⟩).false x
```
The statement is of course the same as your version, but I find a little inelegant to prove `False`.
That does not work unfortunately, since `IsInitial X` is not `Prop`-valued.
Is the corresponding lemma for terminal objects already there?

There is [CategoryTheory.Limits.Types.isTerminalEquivUnique](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/Shapes/Types.html#CategoryTheory.Limits.Types.isTerminalEquivUnique) which is stated in a slightly different form, because `Unique X` is not `Prop`-valued. One can deduce the analogous statement `Nonempty (IsTerminal X) ↔ Nonempty (Unique X)` by applying [Equiv.nonempty_congr](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Logic/Equiv/Defs.html#Equiv.nonempty_congr). I considered adding this as a corollary, but decided against it.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory/Galois): evaluation is injective and more basic properties
